options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The class was a highly interactive lecture setting with ample group activity and discussion that gave it the additional benefits of a seminar environment.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about the place of music theory in academia; we had many discussions analyzing and critiquing the role of the discipline in upholding antiquated, oppressive structures. After taking this class, I feel better prepared to serve as a music theorist for the future, understanding what progress still needs to be made in the field and how we can make positive change. Props to Professor Conlee for being able to work such important discussions into this aural skills course! I also got better at singing random chromatic note sequences, which has been helpful in learning to "audiate" music in my other music theory courses.

I gained a knowledge of many of the labels and frameworks using for understanding harmony and the skills for hearing, analyzing, and embodying them. In addition, I gained a more thoughtful perspective on the cultural theory of how these frameworks come to be in the first place and the hidden curriculum and societal structures that shaped them. Because of this, I gained hands-on experience and a critical lens that went far above and deeply enriched the basic survey of harmonic concepts that I expected.
Advanced music theory especially for ear-training techniques. Techniques in jazz, mediation, and more!
Listening to music and identifying different chords and harmonic structures

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I was so interested in the critical humanism aspect of the course that I wished the course had focused on that entirely -- that's not a criticism of this course, but just a suggestion for another type of course that I would love to see the department offer in the future.

The varied activities - dictation, sight-singing, musical arranging/reharmonization, readings/discussions, presentations - not only helped me practice concepts and succeed but also were consistently challenging and fun. I would have liked to delve even deeper into certain aspects as a whole class, such as Neo-Riemannian Theory and rhythm, but I wouldn't want this to detract from the cultural theory lessons and certainly the presentations provided excellent forays into advanced topics. Overall, I was thrilled with the huge amount of material and gains in confidence I experienced with not much time and the limits of Zoom. The class presentations and interactive questions were my favorite part. They were extremely clear and engaging.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was actually one of the very few classes where I felt that I really got to know the professor. We had multiple on-one-one meetings to discuss our midterm and final presentations, and Professor Conlee was always willing to chat before and after class. It was definitely a challenge to do some of the singing exercises over Zoom, but they worked better than I had thought, and Professor Conlee was very careful to make sure that everything we were doing was successful virtually.

I thought singing together (slowly) over Zoom was surprisingly successful and wouldn't have minded seeing it extended to such challenging topics as diminished chords (crazy, I know, but just an idea). At the same time, the creative assignments such as sight singing and recording arrangements with a DAW were perfect and seemed valuable regardless of whether there was a pandemic during the course or not. The use of breakout rooms during class presentations to practice with classmates was fantastic.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would recommend the course to another student, especially if you are taking it concurrently with MUSI 210 or 211. The topics covered in the course will complement what you are learning in your other music theory courses well. I took this course while taking some more advanced music theory classes, so everything was more or less a review for me, so it wouldn't be my top recommendation for you if you've moved on to more advanced theory (even though Professor Conlee did provide ample opportunities for more advanced students to grow). The critical humanism aspects of the course were really valuable, though, even if the theory wasn't super advanced. The workload is really low, so you could definitely take this class as an extra half-credit.
Absolutely. If you have a solid ear, a grasp of Western music notation, and an interest in harmony especially, the course is extremely rewarding and fun.
Yes! Great way to learn more about music theory and hear better

Yes! This is a really good and practical course that can improve your ability to hear and analyze music. Super useful for any musician. Workload is commensurate to a half-credit course but is actually helpful for learning.
